content: This contribution hasn’t received enough positive votes from the community. The "FASTEST" option has therefore been deactivated.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Fun task! Easier than it looks

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: Nice and fun!
Looks very nice. Once I have time to implement it, I'll upvote it too.

✅ Approved the contribution.
Comment: This is a really good idea and fun to make ! Harder than it seems though ;)

Interesting puzzle, but in my opinion a bit too challenging for clash of code, especially because of the "long targets". I think for clash of code, just restricting to quadratic targets would be more adequate.
I hope you received enough feedback from the community to improve your contribution. Once you have made the necessary updates, publish your contribution!

I like it a lot but why not give the most complex cases as an example? or maybe two have two examples? I know it says that the length of symbols is <= 32 but in a "fastest" clash context I often skip reading the constraints and jump straight to the example(s) so I could have very well assumed there are only 2 symbols
i likey! these are always the fun ones for me
This puzzle seems easy enough for ClashOfCode, and could also appear in "easy" puzzles.
seems like a fun puzzle for clash
This puzzle is good for fastest, shortest modes and classic - easy level

Is the INPUT and STATEMENT parts of the stub generator present in reverse mode? 
There is a lot of hint in there for reverse mode. To much I think.

Code golf? :)

I=input
s=I()
w,h=map(int,input().split())
I('\n'.join(''.join(s[min(r,c,h-r-1,w-c-1)%len(s)]for c in range(w))for r in range(h)))

Basically same idea as goeyj.

Very cool puzzle! I have to agree that tehre seems to be a quick solution out there waiting for us even though i wasn't able to solve it in less than 15 min.
Reverse seems to be quite difficult also...
But good work nonetheless :^)
It will be quite challenging given the time constraints, but overall it's fun to do.

I'd love to know if this puzzle is reasonably doable under 5 minutes; my solution here is a bit complex, but I have a feeling that there exists a much more trivial solution.
Otherwise I suppose this could be a standalone puzzle.

It took me 10 minutes to figure out something that worked for most of the cases, and 20 to finally handle the "Long target" correctly, resulting in something of similar length/complexity to your solution.

I like the concept; it was fun to solve. Quite challenging for a CoC, but that's ok; they don't all have to be trivial. Would also make a good easy-level classic puzzle.
Thanks for your feedback; I hadn't taken the time to  look at your solution yet, but that is a very clean approach!

Thanks for the feedback! I agree that it can be quite challenging; the idea I went with is that the test cases start very trivial, but gradually introduce more edge cases, so even a naive solution can score some points.

Now that I've participated in about a hundred of those clashes, I've noticed that a lot of them are simply "Who can type print(s[::-1]) the fastest?", so I wanted to add something that would be more in the vein of "Let's see who can identify the most edge cases in 15 minutes."

I hope that makes sense!

Oh you know what, that's a good question; because if so yeah that's basically the entire statement in the stub, that's definitely too much for reverse.

The doc doesn't mention anything about reverse when it comes to comments though, so I'm not sure. I'll take a look at the forum when I have time this week.
indeed I thought about quite a complicated solution before guessing it could just be more simple...
